ygData.subject: Re: [archive-crawler] Slowdown in LinkScoper?
ygData.msgSnippet: Two things that first come to mind: (1) Do the URIs they re working on have a gigantic number of outlinks? [*] (2) What Scope are you using? The legacy scopes

From: Gordon Mohr <gojomo@...>
Subject: Re: [archive-crawler] Slowdown in LinkScoper?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=137285340; y=OdGSMoIqIa0qeOfSNeKcH-r4JTU79o_vV6ax5eiP9jU3
X-Yahoo-Profile: gojomo

Two things that first come to mind:

(1) Do the URIs they're working on have a gigantic number of outlinks? [*]

(2) What Scope are you using? The legacy scopes (host/path/domain)
are really inefficient, doing a linear probe through all 'seeds'
to determine if a new URI is in scope. (If using a custom scope,
some other bottleneck could be the cause.) Some thread stacks from
the overly-aged LinksScoper threads could point to the cause.

- Gordon @ IA

Ryan Gran wrote:
> Followup:
> 
> This seems to be progressive.  I launched a new crawl (same order.xml, 
> different seeds), and while I'm
> seeing LinkScoper processors running for 7-10 seconds (still seems 
> long), that's about the extent of it.
> Actually, at the start of the crawl, the majority of threads seem to 
> spend most
> of their time in processor HTTP.  Using the DomainSensitiveFrontier.
> 
> ryanatl wrote:
> 
>
